summary: Email correspondence between Martin Weinberg (Jeffrey Epstein's attorney) and federal prosecutors regarding the unsealing of Epstein's indictment, his upcoming court presentation, and logistical details about the case. The emails discuss timing of indictment unsealing, bail considerations, and delivery of search warrant documents.

persons.name: Martin Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein in the federal case, communicating with prosecutors about indictment unsealing and court procedures.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in the federal criminal case referenced as 'U.S. v. Jeffrey Epstein', represented by Martin Weinberg.

persons.name: Reid
persons.context: Mentioned as planning to call prosecutors with Martin Weinberg regarding the Epstein case.

connections.description: Weinberg is representing Epstein in the federal criminal case, as indicated in the email correspondence with prosecutors.
Working together on the Epstein case, planning to contact prosecutors jointly.

events.title: Indictment Unsealing and Court Assignment
events.description: Prosecutors plan to unseal the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein and have the case assigned to a district judge at approximately 9:15 a.m.

events.title: Epstein's Court Presentation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein will be presented at U.S. District Court at 500 Pearl Street, interviewed by Pretrial Services, and presented before a magistrate or district judge.

events.title: Attorney-Client Meeting
events.description: Martin Weinberg meets with Jeffrey Epstein to discuss the case and potential bail arguments.

locations: 500 Pearl Street (U.S. District Court location in New York)
Law Office of Martin G. Weinberg, P.C.
keyFacts: The indictment against Jeffrey Epstein was returned by a grand jury and was scheduled to be unsealed on July 8, 2019.
Martin Weinberg represented Epstein in the federal criminal case and was coordinating with prosecutors on procedural matters.
Prosecutors anticipated Epstein would consent to detention without prejudice initially, with a bail application to follow in coming days.
A search warrant had been executed at Epstein's property, with privilege issues being considered regarding seized materials.
The case was officially titled 'U.S. v. Jeffrey Epstein' and was proceeding in federal court.
